document.title: Chapter 112. Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Science

74300FBE168B426483062AEB2F776B70.description:
describe how variations of traits within a population lead to structural, behavioral, and
physiological adaptations that influence the likelihood of survival and reproductive
success of a species over generations.

A838A28EA76D4719A1CB30E344DB8DBB.description:
describe the function of genes within chromosomes in determining inherited traits of
offspring; and

2B9CF3662BBE419FB62CC89BACE386D9.description:
identify the function of the cell membrane, cell wall, nucleus, ribosomes, cytoplasm,
mitochondria, chloroplasts, and vacuoles in plant or animal cells;

2ACAC22241EC4B49A904489AB3956956.description:
Organisms and environments. The student knows how cell functions support the health of an
organism and how adaptation and variation relate to survival. The student is expected to:

949060A5A9AD4065A4868F6E7B7D482B.description:
describe how biodiversity contributes to the stability and sustainability of an ecosystem
and the health of the organisms within the ecosystem.

9046AA6F4C0845BB934B2DE2876B6202.description:
describe how primary and secondary ecological succession affect populations and species
diversity after ecosystems are disrupted by natural events or human activity; and

4347E10B477E473BADCBD5616DB83476.description:
explain how disruptions such as population changes, natural disasters, and human
intervention impact the transfer of energy in food webs in ecosystems;

489EA9F786C84144AEBEE82411ADA6FD.description:
Organisms and environments. The student understands stability and change in populations and
ecosystems. The student is expected to:

E4753122183A45F192B849846061FD2F.description:
use scientific evidence to describe how human activities, including the release of
greenhouse gases, deforestation, and urbanization, can influence climate; and

6227E160FEC442AEA34ADB41844F3697.description:
Earth and space. The student knows that natural events and human activity can impact global
climate. The student is expected to:

882ABEE98B9D47348F9330962D9B81D4.description:
describe the interactions between ocean currents and air masses that produce tropical
cyclones, including typhoons and hurricanes.

CDEAE06D551B4415BB59EDD5CBAB1F61.description:
identify global patterns of atmospheric movement and how they influence local weather;
and

CD12417C666C4CC7B7266B147F48E82F.description:
describe how energy from the Sun, hydrosphere, and atmosphere interact and influence
weather and climate;

375C08C7435C4B80B5F42EB72467AA76.description:
Earth and space. The student knows that interactions between Earth, ocean, and weather systems
impact climate. The student is expected to:

D7BC398704AA493683B2E565AF20DDF4.description:
research and analyze scientific data used as evidence to develop scientific theories that
describe the origin of the universe.

982B958C5EF54B3A915ED5E0319D6788.description:
categorize galaxies as spiral, elliptical, and irregular and locate Earth's solar system
within the Milky Way galaxy; and

9E354229D07C431A98A0B00B0AD03B88.description: describe the life cycle of stars and compare and classify stars using the HertzsprungRussell diagram;

794833EA70DB42F6A8B1397C64C09868.description:
Earth and space. The student describes the characteristics of the universe and the relative scale of
its components. The student is expected to:

8D99A2A5485B449BB6AA08A894C1DA95.description:
explain the use of electromagnetic waves in applications such as radiation therapy,
wireless technologies, fiber optics, microwaves, ultraviolet sterilization, astronomical
observations, and X-rays.

D63DEBF2DA6B4DB2B321BE0EFCDF6E5A.description:
compare the characteristics of amplitude, frequency, and wavelength in transverse waves,
including the electromagnetic spectrum; and

F3E14AF142DB49C6BF1AA62BB06C9FE9.description:
Force, motion, and energy. The student knows how energy is transferred through waves. The
student is expected to:

F113178321F74E7A9223A2E3F1D5AE0E.description:
investigate and describe how Newton's three laws of motion act simultaneously within
systems such as in vehicle restraints, sports activities, amusement park rides, Earth's
tectonic activities, and rocket launches.

3475462122064D0EAB3254FCCAF6D7CB.description:
Force, motion, and energy. The student understands the relationship between force and motion
within systems. The student is expected to:

A4B60C95059348FCAB0AD794B85C90BC.description:
investigate how mass is conserved in chemical reactions and relate conservation of mass
to the rearrangement of atoms using chemical equations, including photosynthesis.

BBC369CC8C424ACE8E14B52D869826ED.description:
compare and contrast the properties of acids and bases, including pH relative to water;
and

D91A356C77884970834CBB55DDFB34AE.description: use the periodic table to identify the atoms involved in chemical reactions;

22D9E7B5F2A04514B095B6B9B532B301.description:
explain by modeling how matter is classified as elements, compounds, homogeneous
mixtures, or heterogeneous mixtures;

05628F9E3A9B48E0A867C76C5F88F7DA.description:
Matter and energy. The student understands that matter can be classified according to its
properties and matter is conserved in chemical changes that occur within closed systems. The
student is expected to:

33010DE87FEE409FBE3A9A22A01F6AED.description:
analyze and explain how factors or conditions impact stability and change in objects,
organisms, and systems.

179166F564904212993AB9CF782C9B3E.description:
analyze and explain the complementary relationship between the structure and function
of objects, organisms, and systems; and

A032BC72AB404542932E563B238349F6.description:
analyze and explain how energy flows and matter cycles through systems and how
energy and matter are conserved through a variety of systems;

BBACF0ACE243436D8FACDE479955A11C.description:
examine and model the parts of a system and their interdependence in the function of the
system;

32030E1373124940A3E81B6A71BDA1A3.description:
analyze how differences in scale, proportion, or quantity affect a system's structure or
performance;

6B77D51959BD4C4DA6F6C22831A9A627.description:
identify and investigate cause-and-effect relationships to explain scientific phenomena or
analyze problems;

050949D03E124E8EA44FAECB1FB1107F.description:
identify and apply patterns to understand and connect scientific phenomena or to design
solutions;

60A5974F71B04A3FAB9CCE03B4F8EB9F.description:
Recurring themes and concepts. The student understands that recurring themes and concepts
provide a framework for making connections across disciplines. The student is expected to:

AF5268CA2EC64EDF8283377A083C1B33.description:
make informed decisions by evaluating evidence from multiple appropriate sources to
assess the credibility, accuracy, cost-effectiveness, and methods used; and

5998985490474A90A6A72BFF4D03DC1D.description:
Scientific and engineering practices. The student knows the contributions of scientists and
recognizes the importance of scientific research and innovation on society. The student is expected
to:

CBB90BF473FD462081082953153646E2.description:
engage respectfully in scientific argumentation using applied scientific explanations and
empirical evidence.

B5B14BB8DB7940A8A4AE721CD5007457.description:
communicate explanations and solutions individually and collaboratively in a variety of
settings and formats; and

F05D1B83329047F7890D376057DC5D2A.description:
develop explanations and propose solutions supported by data and models and consistent
with scientific ideas, principles, and theories;

FC3C14F01FA74F2C8BC1AEA059BE8F9C.description:
Scientific and engineering practices. The student develops evidence-based explanations and
communicates findings, conclusions, and proposed solutions. The student is expected to:

E41E51C466BB46FDADF4FAB5F90A1292.description: use mathematical calculations to assess quantitative relationships in data; and

56353F7A233E4CDC80891E562CF67ACD.description:
analyze data by identifying any significant descriptive statistical features, patterns,
sources of error, or limitations;

9D04093BCECE4895B7664AF8C4683079.description:
identify advantages and limitations of models such as their size, scale, properties, and
materials;

F78966621673474EB605C1D7EA0F5EC7.description:
Scientific and engineering practices. The student analyzes and interprets data to derive meaning,
identify features and patterns, and discover relationships or correlations to develop evidence-based
arguments or evaluate designs. The student is expected to:

342192F71DBF4D2582A32150077343E8.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses, theories, and laws.

4AD6FE35059B44CAAF38EC3DC3DB519C.description:
develop and use models to represent phenomena, systems, processes, or solutions to
engineering problems; and

D6B11BA396E24CAD8BB5D6119ADA37B4.description:
construct appropriate tables, graphs, maps, and charts using repeated trials and means to
organize data;

4DD13FBF05854938849F3C62A7A2CF8D.description:
collect quantitative data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative data
as evidence;

E9718D50515B4A0880C0E3EBFD3E9338.description:
use appropriate tools such as graduated cylinders, metric rulers, periodic tables, balances,
scales, thermometers, temperature probes, laboratory ware, timing devices, pH indicators, hot plates, models, microscopes, slides, life science models, petri dishes, dissecting kits,
magnets, spring scales or force sensors, tools that model wave behavior, satellite images,
weather maps, hand lenses, and lab notebooks or journals;

79E8B8ED3A754A4D825D61D3628B1DE5.description:
use appropriate safety equipment and practices during laboratory, classroom, and field
investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards;

9870DA73093542BA9BAC8D4E51AD18A4.description:
use scientific practices to plan and conduct descriptive, comparative, and experimental
investigations and use engineering practices to design solutions to problems;

CBE8A418EC134796A27CC6CFAE8C5405.description:
ask questions and define problems based on observations or information from text,
phenomena, models, or investigations;

BF75E4FBA5D4458FBE1729BE6A196126.description:
Scientific and engineering practices. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, asks
questions, identifies problems, and plans and safely conducts classroom, laboratory, and field
investigations to answer questions, explain phenomena, or design solutions using appropriate tools
and models. The student is expected to:

9A8335C22B7B4C3DB7279637F6223DD6.description:
Statements containing the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those
containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

6BC3E202F35B4D13BD52F71E41F3D654.description:
Recurring themes and concepts. Science consists of recurring themes and making connections
between overarching concepts. Recurring themes include structure and function, systems, models,
and patterns. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and
matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and
modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Models have
limitations but provide a tool for understanding the ideas presented. Students analyze a system in
terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the
external environment.

F4D75F54BE224558AC945D15DE21245D.description:
Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the
natural world involving its own set of ethical standards about how the process of science should be
carried out. Students distinguish between scientific decision-making practices and ethical and
social decisions that involve science.

0E549E4E54FE40AA887F8B868F09CE93.description:
scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being
tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well
established and highly reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new
areas of science and new technologies are developed.

354219B01C1C4B8199D53E37D2845C98.description:
hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported
or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power
that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories; and

716DA3D35BFE4C86A3CADB9109EBEDA5.description:
inferences are conclusions reached on the basis of observations or reasoning supported by
relevant evidence;

A2E00B9134D443A283510E3EF8A32672.description:
observations are active acquisition of either qualitative or quantitative information from a
primary source through the senses;

E668438AB47E47E6A6C44F19690CB4E7.description: Scientific observations, inferences, hypotheses, and theories. Students are expected to know that:

B271BD57783A46D19210D743453A9C63.description:
Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of
evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the
knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge
is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some
questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not currently
scientifically testable.

0BC3535A7ABA4CCD9D085994EDB088C7.description:
Organisms and environments. Students identify the function of organelles. Traits are
contained in genetic material that is found on genes within a chromosome from the parent. These traits influence the success of a species over time. Students explore how
organisms and their populations respond to environmental changes, including those
caused by human activities.

7B6D18202F824AC2B989BE0C127C1C83.description:
Earth and space. Students learn that stars and galaxies are part of the universe. In
addition, students use data to research scientific theories of the origin of the universe.
Students learn how interactions in solar, weather, and ocean systems create changes in
weather patterns and climate. In addition, students understand that climate can be
impacted by natural events and human activities.

1699798644FB454CAC848279AA01118E.description:
Force, motion, and energy. Students are introduced to Newton's Second Law of Motion
and investigate how all three laws of motion act simultaneously within systems. Students
understand that waves transfer energy and further explore the characteristics and
applications of waves.

DC6504E4CFBF4314A6544100636D767C.description:
Matter and energy. Students make connections between elements, compounds, and
mixtures that were introduced in prior grade levels. Students examine the properties of
water, acids, and bases. In addition, students understand the basic concept of conservation
of mass using chemical equations.

EF1CC11872FD4280B43C343E8B0D0FA4.description:
Engineering practices. Students identify problems and design solutions using
appropriate tools and models.

6DA5F03A3C114119B534AB8206710903.description:
Scientific practices. Students ask questions, plan and conduct investigations to
answer questions, and explain phenomena using appropriate tools and models.

7F1DB0521D304E88A11D5C306879EA21.description:
Scientific and engineering practices. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate
investigation of the natural world using scientific and engineering practices. Scientific
methods of investigation are descriptive, correlative, comparative, or experimental. The
method chosen should be appropriate to the grade level and question being asked. Student
learning for different types of investigations includes descriptive investigations, which
have no hypothesis that tentatively answers the research question and involve collecting
data and recording observations without making comparisons; correlative and
comparative investigations, which have a hypothesis that predicts a relationship and
involve collecting data, measuring variables relevant to the hypothesis that are
manipulated, and comparing results; and experimental investigations, which involve
processes similar to comparative investigations but in which a hypothesis can be tested
by comparing a treatment with a control.

3DEBB31892B049058CF6DA76817980FF.description:
In Grades 6 through 8 Science, content is organized into recurring strands. The concepts within
each grade level build on prior knowledge, prepare students for the next grade level, and establish
a foundation for high school courses. In Grade 8, the following concepts will be addressed in each
strand.
